'''Waldo Emerson Bailey''' (November 16, 1896 – April 24, 1961) was a noted American [[Consul (representative)|Consul]] who held numerous positions in the [[United States Foreign Service|U.S. Foreign Service]] during the first half of the 20th century.
==Biography== Waldo Bailey was born on November 16, 1896, in Winona, Mississippi, the youngest of 11 children.<ref name=Dhahran>[http://imgsrv2.aramcoexpats.com/sun_flare/1947/SUN35_05071947.pdf Meet the American Consul at Dhahran, ''Arabian Sun & Flare'', Vol. 2, No. 35 (May 7, 1947)] Retrieved 2015-07-31.</ref> During World War I, he served overseas in the [[United States Marine Corp|U.S. Marine Corp]] and was discharged in 1919.<ref name=Dhahran/>
===Education=== In 1920, Bailey received a [[Bachelor of Science|BS degree]] from [[Mississippi State University|Mississippi Agricultural and Mechanical College]], and attended [[Pittsburg State University|Kansas State Teachers College of Pittsburg]] in 1924.<ref name=Register>[https://archive.org/stream/registercontaini1929unit/registercontaini1929unit_djvu.txt Register of the Department of State (January 1, 1929), Section XVIII. Biography: Persons serving under appointment of the Department of State] Retrieved 2015-08-02.</ref> In 1927, he received a [[Master of Arts|MA degree]] from [[Peabody College|Peabody College for Teachers]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name=Register/>
===Career=== In 1923, Waldo Bailey began his career with the U.S. Foreign Service; his first assignment was as a consular clerk in [[Karachi]], then [[Calcutta]].<ref name=Dhahran/> In 1925, Bailey served as platform superintendent on a [[Chautauqua circuit]].<ref name=Register/>
====Foreign Service assignments==== U.S. [[Vice Consul]]:<ref name=Register/><ref name=Grave>[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/bailey9.html Bailey, Waldo Emerson, ''The Political Graveyard''] Retrieved 2015-08-01.</ref> *[[Rosario, Santa Fe]], [[Argentina]], 1926–27 *[[Mazatlán]], [[Mexico]], 1928–29 *[[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]], 1932 *[[Lyon]], [[France]], 1935 *[[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]], 1938 *[[Diplomatic rank|Second Secretary]] of Embassy and Consul in London, 1941–42 U.S. Consul in London, 1943<ref>[https://familysearch.org/patron/v2/TH-300-45405-569-80/dist.pdf?ctx=ArtCtxPublic ''The London Gazette'' (23 April 1943)] Retrieved 2015-08-01.</ref>
In September 1943, Bailey resigned from the Foreign Service to join the [[United States Navy]] and serve in [[World War II]].<ref name =Dhahran/> He was discharged in June 1944. After his discharge, he volunteered as an ambulance driver for the [[Eighth Army (United Kingdom)|British 8th Army]] and served in [[Italy]]. After duty in Italy, he volunteered to serve with the [[Fourteenth Army (United Kingdom)|British 14th Army]] in [[Burma]] and [[India]] until 1945.<ref>[http://www.ourstory.info/library/Rock/roster.html Roster of American Field Service Volunteers 1939-1945] Retrieved 2015-08-01.</ref>
When the war ended, Bailey rejoined the U.S. Foreign Service and was assigned as American Consul in [[Vancouver]], [[Canada]] in 1946.<ref name=Bio>[https://archive.org/stream/registercontaini1950unit/registercontaini1950unit_djvu.txt Register of the Department of State (June 6, 1950), Section XII. Biographies: Personnel of the Department of State and of the Foreign Service] Retrieved 2015-08-2.</ref> In 1946-47, Bailey became U.S. Consul in [[Dhahran]], then Second Secretary and Consul in [[Jiddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]], and in [[Sana'a]], [[Yemen]].<ref name=Bio/>
By November 1947, Bailey had become Consul in [[Tijuana]], [[Mexico]], then Consul in [[Mumbai|Bombay]], [[India]] by December 1949.<ref name=Bio/> While in Foreign Service, Bailey traveled to 82 foreign countries and served on all continents, with the exception of [[Australia]].<ref name=Dhahran/>
===Death=== Waldo Bailey died on April 24, 1961, and was interred in [[Cedar Lawn Cemetery (Jackson, Mississippi)|Cedar Lawn Cemetery]], Jackson, Mississippi.<ref name=Grave/>
